sentences: Paul Williams (December 1, 1934 – April 24, 2016), known professionally as Billy Paul, was a Grammy Award-winning American soul singer, known for his 1972 No. 1 single "Me and Mrs. Jones", as well as the 1973 album and single War of the Gods, which blends his more conventional pop, soul, and funk styles with electronic and psychedelic influences.
section: N/A

sentences: He was one of the many artists associated with the Philadelphia soul sound created by Kenny Gamble, Leon Huff, and Thom Bell.
section: N/A

sentences: Paul was identified by his diverse vocal style, which ranged from mellow and soulful to low and raspy.
section: N/A

sentences: Questlove of the Roots equated Paul with Marvin Gaye and Stevie Wonder, calling him "one of the criminally unmentioned proprietors of socially conscious post-revolution '60s civil rights music."
section: N/A

sentences: In 1952, he traveled to New York City and entered the recording studio for Jubilee Records.
section: == Life and career == | === First recordings ===

sentences: Backed by Tadd Dameron on piano and Jackie Davis on the Hammond organ, Paul released his first single that April: "Why Am I" with "That's Why I Dream" as the B-side (Jubilee Records 5081, both written by Bernard Sacks and B. Sidney Zeff).
section: == Life and career == | === First recordings ===

sentences: Billboard reviewed the tracks favorably, saying of "Why Am I" that it was "Expressive warbling of a moody ballad, by the label's new 16-year-old chanter", and of "That's Why I Dream": "Organ and piano lend the singer a hand in this slow-paced etching of a romantic number".
section: == Life and career == | === First recordings ===

sentences: In June 1952, Paul released his second single – this time collaborating with the Buddy Lucas Orchestra – "You Didn't Know", backed with "The Stars Are Mine" (Jubilee Records 5086).
section: == Life and career == | === First recordings ===

sentences: Billboard was again positive, saying about "You Didn't Know" – "Billy Paul, new young singer, makes an impressive bow on the label with a strong performance of a weeper ballad which should pick up spins and plays.

sentences: The Lucas ork furnishes okay backing.
section: == Life and career == | === First recordings ===

sentences: A good disk" and about "The Stars Are Mine" – "Paul sings this new tune more quietly, over a smooth ork reading.

sentences: Side is not as exciting as flip and tune is not as strong."
section: == Life and career == | === First recordings ===

sentences: After Neptune folded, Gamble and Huff started their third label – Philadelphia International Records (PIR) – and brought Paul with them.

sentences: Gamble and Huff signed a distribution deal with Clive Davis and CBS Records.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Philadelphia International releases ====

sentences: Going East (1971) was the first Billy Paul album released on the Philadelphia International Records label, making full use of the label's regular group of ace musicians MFSB at Sigma Sound Studios.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Philadelphia International releases ====

sentences: As they had done on the previous LP, Gamble and Huff sought to find the balance between Paul's jazz roots and the funky soul that they hoped would  bring mainstream success.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Philadelphia International releases ====

sentences: Paul nearly reached the charts with the single "Magic Carpet Ride" (cover of the 1968 Steppenwolf hit) and the album climbed to No. 42 on the Billboard soul chart and No. 197 on the pop chart.

== Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: In 2000, Nike began airing a commercial featuring track and field star Marion Jones – the face of Team USA for the 2000 Summer Olympics, winning five medals, which were all later stripped from her for cheating.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: The campaign, entitled "Mrs. Jones", depicted the athlete as a half-hidden DJ talking about issues such as education and better pay for female athletes.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: The ad also featured Paul's studio recording of "Me and Mrs. Jones".
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Paul saw the commercial and contacted an attorney, who filed suit in a federal district court in Los Angeles against both the sportswear company and its advertising agency, Wieden & Kennedy.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Paul sought $1 million in lost licensing fees, arguing that the company had cheated him by not obtaining his permission to use the song.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: A spokesperson for the ad agency called the decision to air the song without permission "a very stupid mistake.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: "On the heels of the Nike suit, Paul targeted his former record company for unpaid royalties on his signature song.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: He claimed that he had not received an accounting statement from Philadelphia International Records in 27 years and sued Assorted Music, its owners Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff, and Sony Music Entertainment for nearly half a million dollars.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: At the 2003 trial in a federal district court in Los Angeles, Joseph E. Porter, the attorney for Assorted Music, argued that Paul was only owed about $27,000, explaining that while the company had mistakenly failed to collect proper foreign royalties on the record, Paul actually owed the company about $314,000 for the costs of recording and producing the 10 albums he made for Philadelphia International from 1971 to 1980.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: In the end, the jury deliberated for less than an hour and found that Paul did not owe the company anything.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Instead, they awarded him half a million dollars in unpaid royalties for his recording of "Me and Mrs. Jones."
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Paul said through a statement issued by his attorney: "I'm so glad my path to justice has finally come to an end.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: I've been waiting years to be paid for my recordings."
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Seymour Straus, who testified at trial on Paul's behalf commented: "There is no question that Billy Paul's royalties had been improperly calculated for many years."
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Jay Berger of the Artists Rights Enforcement Corporation said: "This case firmly establishes the rights of singers signed to small production companies to receive 50% of the money earned by the major labels that distribute the records."
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Chuck Rubin the president of Artists Rights said: "The producers will no longer walk off with any of the artist's royalties."
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: Paul's lawyer Steven Ames Brown commented: "It was a stunning victory for Billy.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: The jury awarded him $12,000 more than we requested.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: The years of deception and excuses are over and Billy Paul will from now on enjoy the fruits of his talents.
section: == Life and career == | === "Me and Mrs. Jones" lawsuits ===

sentences: In 2009, the biographical feature film Am I Black Enough for You?, directed by Swedish director Göran Hugo Olsson, was released.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Feature film ====

sentences: Awarding the film three stars, Uncut magazine said "Olsson modelled his film on Let’s Get Lost, Bruce Weber’s 1989 portrait of Chet Baker, saying: "Paul is certainly no fallen demi-genius to set alongside Baker, but he proves an engaging, articulate subject, with a story that stretches back to playing alongside Charlie Parker, and peppered with the usual racial prejudice.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Feature film ====

== Life and career == | === Awards and honors ===

sentences: Awards and honors ===
section: == Life and career == | === Awards and honors ===

sentences: In addition to receiving the Grammy for "Me and Mrs. Jones", Paul won several Ebby awards given by the readers of Ebony magazine; was a recipient of an American Music Award, the NAACP Image Award and numerous proclamations and keys to cities across the United States.
section: == Life and career == | === Awards and honors ===

sentences: Paul received the 2015 AMG Favorite Retro Artist of the Year award, as well as being given the Sandy Hosey Lifetime Achievement Award during the Artists Music Guild's 2015 AMG Heritage Awards broadcast held on November 14, 2015, in Monroe, North Carolina.
section: == Life and career == | === Awards and honors ===

sentences: In 2010 Questlove of the Roots equated Paul with Marvin Gaye and Stevie Wonder, calling him "one of the criminally unmentioned proprietors of socially conscious post-revolution '60s civil rights music."
section: == Life and career == | === Awards and honors ===
